name.text: Calculating the surface area of a cone from its net.

questiontext.text:

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

To find the surface area of a cone using its net, you need to calculate the areas of the circular base and the curved surface which unfolds into a sector of a circle and then add them together.

\(\begin{align}\text{The total surface area of a cone}&=\frac{\theta}{360} \pi r^2 + \pi r^2 \end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of a sector}&=\frac{\theta}{360} \pi r^2\\&=\frac{{@selected_angle @}}{360} \times \frac{22}{7} \times {@selected_radius @} cm\times {@selected_radius @} cm\\&={@area_of_sector@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of the circle}&=\pi r^2\\&=\frac{22}{7} \times {@radius_circle@} cm\times {@radius_circle@}cm\\&={@area_of_circle@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Total surface area}&={@area_of_sector@} cm^2 +{@area_of_circle@} cm^2\\&={@surface_area@} cm^2\end{align}\)

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have only calculated the curved part of the cone. Don’t forget that the base, a circle is also part of the surface area. A complete cone includes both the curved surface and the circular base. You’re close! Just remember to add in the area of the base and give it another shot.

It seems like you might have mixed up the formulas. It looks like you used the one for arc length instead of the area of a sector. Easy mistake! Just remember, arc length tells you how long the edge is, while surface area needs the whole space inside the curved surface. Take another look at the formula for area of a sector and try again — you’re definitely on the right path
